Seventh graders are studying the Spanish, French, English, and Dutch colonies and how these settlements were created and the relationship that existed with the natives they encountered. Students will be creating a historical marker to commemorate the colony and explain how a country established the territorial claim, what their relationship was with the natives, and if the settlement failed or flourished. In addition, students will continue to learn how the English colonists developed a distinct "American" identity and how they moved toward the American Revolution.

Thank you to 7th grade I &S teacher Katia Marques for organizing this wonderful hands-on experience for students and to Waterside Forge re-enactors.for demonstrations of colonial era blacksmithing and traditional crafts.

Dobbs Ferry School District added 32 new photos to the album: DFMS Design Class "Make-a-Shoe".
September 11, 2017 at 1:09 PM ·

The first project of the year in 8th grade Design class was a big "step" for students! They had to Make-a-Shoe using only the elements that were available on the table at the front of the room.

DFMS teacher JP Kaminski wanted his students to take a chance, so he was not assigning grades. The only criteria for the shoes were:
1. They had to be durable- must be able to walk 45 feet in them
2. They must be comfortable
3. They must be fashionable

Working in teams, the students had to design and build their shoes using various materials including styrofoam, rope, cardboard, cotton balls,glue,colored paper, markers, tape etc. The final "test" would be to walk in the completed footwear.

The students are learning skills like drawing a model, following construction plans, thinking our of the box, figuring out the right questions to ask and completing an open-ended assignment successfully.

Mr. Kaminski recently presented at the IB MYP Conference in Atlanta in June and did this very same activity with the teachers. Everyone got a big kick out of it!

DFMS 8th graders were fortunate to have guest speaker Maud Dahme, a Holocaust survivor, speak to them yesterday about her experiences as a “hidden child” from 1942 to 1944 in the Netherlands. Ms. Dahme is the former president of the New Jersey Board of Education and she has guided many teachers on trips to Europe to visit the concentration camps. She is committed to educating teachers and students about the Holocaust and genocide.
In I&S 8 classes, students had a mini-unit on the Holocaust focusing on the timeline of events leading to the Holocaust from the end of World War I (1918) to the end of World War II (1945). Mr. Poccia showed his class a film entitled, The Path To Nazi Genocide. An amazing woman! See you tube video for Ms. Dahme's story. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ds6m1zsBXpU

The Dobbs Ferry School District has officially received International Baccalaureate (IB) Middle Years Programme (MYP) authorization. Dobbs Ferry Middle School can now be formally recognized as an International Baccalaureate World School, as part of the MYP partnership with Dobbs Ferry High School. At the heart of both programs is the IB Learner Profile, which defines “international-mindedness” and aligns to the District’s overall mission and vision… Independent Thinkers Prepared to Change the World. Next week our District is hosting an important community education event, and we would like to invite you to attend. On Tuesday, April 19 at 7:30, nationally-recognized organization and time management expert Leslie Josel will present, "It's 10:00 p.m.—Do You Know Where Your Homework is?" sponsored by Rivertown Parents. The presentation is designed for parents of 5th-10th graders but is open to all. Our own Doug Berry has graciously agreed to introduce the speaker.
We chose this topic because organization and time management skills are critical to our students' ability to succeed in school and in life. Having heard Leslie speak in the past, we know she will provide practical, concrete tips and techniques to benefit students of diverse ages and learning styles. In addition, we hope her interactive presentation style will give you a chance to hear about the needs and concerns of local families.

post_text: 6th grade Language and Literature classes participated in an enrichment activity today, based on the novel, The Giver. Students were placed into small groups and moved through different stations. At each station, students were asked to look at a "Magic Eye" picture. Embedded in the picture were images that are only visible to some of the students after staring at the picture for some time. The activity was designed to allow the students to experience some of the feelings the main character, Jonah, has during the novel. He is able to see beyond the boundaries of his world and is frustrated when others can't see what he is seeing. The students had a good time participating in this activity!

On Wednesday, October 28th, 7th grade students took part in the annual Colonial Day to learn about life in Colonial America, Thanks to funding from the Dobbs Ferry PTSA and the School District, the students were able to engage with Waterside Forge re-enactors and make history come alive.
Students participated in hands-on workshops set up in the High School gym (due to bad weather). They learned how textiles were made, what games children played, cooking skills and ingredients and medicinal practices of the 18th century. They also had the opportunity to learn colonial trades, such as coopering and blacksmithing, as well as hear about the struggles of our Revolutionary soldiers. Thanks to Katia Marques, 7th grade social studies teacher and event coordinator for making Colonial Day a great success!

Eighth-Grade Writing for the Real World class Visits Springhurst

After writing and publishing their own children’s books, the eighth-grade Writing for the Real World class visited the elementary students at Springhurst to read their stories and have a question and answer session. Before generating their own stories, the eighth-graders evaluated a variety of popular children’s books for the theme, types of characters and conflicts that young children enjoy in stories. Then students began brainstorming their own ideas and creating storyboards for their books. They used online software called Storyboard that as a tool to illustrate their stories and to craft their text.
Writing for the Real World is an exploratory writing class for eighth-graders with the purpose of writing for authentic audiences. These students couldn’t have had a more authentic audience than a group of young children to listen to their stories! This event is also a great way to bring together the two schools and to unify the younger children with the older students as positive role models.
